It turned, its movements both jerky and horribly fluid, and began to scuttle not away, but towards her.

Something inside Mariam, some carefully constructed wall of piety and order, did not just crack. It shattered. A scream tore from her throat, a sound she didn’t recognize as her own. It was raw, animal, stripped of all reason and faith. She crab-walked backward, her hands slipping in the sticky brine of the broken lemon jar. She couldn’t take her eyes off it. The way its legs moved, a nightmare of synchronized pistons. The oily sheen on its back. The absolute, mindless purpose in its advance.

“Sister, for the love of God!” Agnes snapped, but her voice was distant, a sound from another world.

The creature was at the edge of her habit. It paused, its antennae twitching, seeming to test the black fabric. Mariam’s breath hitched. She imagined it crawling up her leg, the tickle of its bristly limbs on her skin, the foulness of it beneath the layers of her sanctified clothing. She flailed, kicking out, her foot connecting with nothing. The scream became a high, keening whimper. She scrambled to her feet, stumbling over her own robes, and fled. She burst past a stunned Sister Agnes, out of the pantry, through the kitchen, and into the central courtyard, where she finally collapsed onto the cool tiles, gasping for air, her body trembling in violent, uncontrollable waves. She was no longer Sister Mariam, the keeper of words and order. She was just a raw nerve of terror, convinced she could still feel the phantom touch of chitin on her skin.

The days that followed were a blur of shame and persistent fear. The power was restored within the hour, but the light inside Mariam had been extinguished. The convent, once her sanctuary, had become a landscape of potential horrors. Every shadow in a corner held a waiting menace. A rustle of leaves in the courtyard was the skittering of a hundred legs. She found herself scanning walls, ceilings, the floor beneath her feet, her body perpetually coiled, ready to flinch. She could not enter the kitchen, let alone the pantry. At meals, she would stare at her food, her stomach churning, imagining a stray insect wing in her soup, a leg in her rice. She took to eating only bread and water in the solitude of her cell.

The other nuns tried to be kind, at first. Sister Therese, young and sweet-natured, left a small wildflower on her desk. Sister Agnes, in a rare display of gentleness, told her she had scrubbed the pantry from top to bottom with bleach. “Nothing could live through that, Mariam. It’s clean.”

But their patience, rooted in practicality, soon wore thin. Her fear was irrational, an indulgence. They lived in a hot climate; insects were a fact of life, like the heat and the dust. One dealt with them. One did not fall apart.

A week after the incident, Mother Elena summoned her to her office. The Abbess was a formidable woman, her piety as sharp and unyielding as the crucifix that hung on her wall. She did not believe in coddling. She believed in spiritual fortitude.

“Sit, Mariam,” she said, her voice devoid of its usual warmth. The office was cool and orderly, smelling of beeswax and roses from the vase on her desk. It felt like a deliberate contrast to Mariam’s inner chaos.

Mariam sat, her hands clenched in her lap, her eyes fixed on a point just past the Abbess’s shoulder.

“I have been hearing… reports,” Mother Elena began, steepling her fingers. “That you are not eating. That you have abandoned your duties in the scriptorium. That Sister Agnes found you weeping in the chapel because a beetle flew in through the window.”

Mariam’s throat was tight. She could only nod, the movement jerky.

“This is not you, Mariam. You are a woman of discipline. Of order.” Mother Elena leaned forward, her dark eyes intense. “What is this weakness? God created all creatures, the great and the small. The dove and the serpent. The lamb and the locust. To recoil in such a way from one of His creations… it is a failure of faith. It suggests you find a flaw in His divine plan.”

“Mother, I… I can’t control it,” Mariam whispered, the words tasting like ash. “When I see one, I… the world disappears. There is only… that.”

“Then you must pray harder,” the Abbess said, her tone final. “You must conquer this. It is a trial, a test of your spirit. The Devil finds purchase in our fears. You are allowing him to sow discord in this house, and in your soul. I expect you to resume your duties tomorrow. I will hear no more of this… hysteria.”

The word hung in the air between them. *Hysteria*. It was a judgment, a branding. Mariam left the office feeling smaller and more alone than ever. Her fear was not just a weakness; it was a sin. A stain on her soul. That night, she knelt by her cot, her rosary beads clutched in her sweating palm, and prayed until her knees ached. She prayed for strength, for peace, for deliverance. But the image that came to her mind was not the serene face of the Madonna. It was the quivering antennae and slick, jointed legs of the creature in the dark. Her prayers felt hollow, unheard.

Her work in the scriptorium became a torment. The quiet room was no longer a refuge. She imagined silverfish crawling from the spines of the old books, booklice teeming invisibly on the pages. A dead moth found between the pages of a psalter sent her into a fit of trembling that lasted an hour. Her ability to focus, to find solace in the order of the text, was gone. The chaos had followed her here.

It was during one such moment, as she stared blankly at a Latin text on medicinal herbs, her mind replaying the pantry incident for the thousandth time, that a new figure entered her diminished world. The convent had long employed tutors for specialized subjects, and Mother Elena, perhaps in a last-ditch effort to impose structure on Mariam’s unraveling mind, had decided the old botanical manuscripts needed not just cataloging, but translation.

His name was Mr. Elias Saliba. He was a retired university professor, a Maronite from Lebanon who had lived in Jeddah for thirty years. He was a small, neat man with a fringe of white hair, spectacles that sat low on his nose, and hands stained with what looked like ink and earth. He had a reputation as a brilliant, if eccentric, botanist.

He arrived on a sweltering afternoon, carrying a worn leather satchel. Mother Elena performed the introduction with brisk formality and then left them alone in the scriptorium. An awkward silence descended. Mr. Elias surveyed the shelves with an appreciative eye.

“A fine collection,” he murmured, his voice a soft, gravelly hum. “A very fine collection indeed.”

He turned to the table where Mariam sat, her posture rigid. He pulled out a chair and sat opposite her, placing his spectacles on his nose and peering at the open manuscript.

“*De herbis et plantis*,” he read. “A classic. Mostly plagiarized from Dioscorides, of course, but with some fascinating local additions. See this entry here? On the properties of *Calotropis procera*? The locals call it the Sodom apple. Quite poisonous, but in the right hands…”

He trailed off, noticing she wasn’t looking at the book. Her eyes were fixed on the large window, her expression one of frozen dread. A common housefly, fat and iridescent, was buzzing insistently against the glass, trying to get out. It was a small, stupid sound, but to Mariam it was a roar. Her knuckles were white where she gripped the edge of the table. Her breathing was shallow.

Mr. Elias watched her for a long moment. He didn't speak. He didn't sigh in exasperation or quote scripture. He simply rose from his chair, walked calmly to the window, and unlatched it. He gently cupped his hands around the fly, a gesture as delicate as if he were holding a jewel, and released it into the humid air outside. He then closed and latched the window again.

He returned to his seat. He picked up the manuscript as if nothing had happened. He looked at her over the top of his spectacles, and for the first time since that night in the pantry, Mariam felt seen. Not judged, not pitied, but simply seen.

“Now,” Mr. Elias said, his voice quiet and kind. “This particular passage on poultices is rather poorly translated in the French edition. I was hoping your Latin was strong. Shall we?”

The question hung in the quiet air, a simple invitation. “Shall we?” It was not a command, not an expectation, but a gentle offering, a hand extended across the chasm of her terror. For a week, Mariam had been drowning, and everyone around her had told her to simply stop. This man, this stranger, had seen her flailing and, instead of judging the water, had quietly pointed to a piece of driftwood. It was not a rescue, not yet, but it was the first thing she had been able to grab onto. Her gaze, which had been fixed on the window, slowly, reluctantly, dropped to the manuscript on the table. The Latin script, usually so clear and orderly, swam before her eyes. She took a breath, a ragged, shuddering thing, but a breath nonetheless.

“Yes,” she whispered, her voice rusty from disuse. “The… the French edition is a poor copy. It misses the nuance.” It was the first time in days she had spoken of her work with anything approaching her old authority. Her mind, grateful for a familiar task, latched onto the problem. She pointed a trembling finger to a line of text. “Here. *Pulveris et mellis mixturam*. They translate it as a ‘powdered honey mixture,’ but the grammar implies two separate elements in the poultice. A powder *and* honey, applied together.”

Mr. Elias leaned in, his own finger tracing the line below hers, his nail neatly trimmed and clean. He smelled faintly of carbolic soap and old books. “Exactly. And look here, the next line mentions *radix scillae*. Sea squill. A powerful diuretic and heart stimulant. Highly toxic if mishandled. If you simply mixed it into the honey, the dosage would be uncontrollable. But as a separate dusting of powder… that is a far more precise, and safer, application. You have a very good eye, Sister.”

Their sessions fell into a pattern that became the new center of Mariam’s fractured world. He would arrive at two o'clock, just as the afternoon heat reached its zenith, and they would work until the Asr prayer call echoed across the rooftops. He spoke of the world of plants not as a divine, abstract creation, but as a complex, interconnected system of survival and propagation. He explained how the desert rose secreted a milky, toxic sap to deter herbivores, how the frankincense tree’s resin was a response to a wound in its bark, a healing balm. He spoke of insects not as aberrations, but as essential partners and antagonists in this silent, slow-motion drama: the wasps that pollinated figs, the beetles that bored into wood, the ants that carried seeds.

His world was as ordered as her own had once been, but his was a messier, more pragmatic order. It was a system that accounted for poison, for decay, for the things that scuttled in the dark. He wasn't telling her not to be afraid; he was simply showing her a world where these things had a place, a name, a function. He was cataloging the chaos that had overwhelmed her, putting it on a shelf in a different way. During their time together, the scriptorium once again became a sanctuary, not from the world, but within it. The small space around their table, illuminated by the dusty shafts of afternoon light, became an island of focused calm. Her fear did not vanish. It was a low hum beneath the surface of her thoughts, a shadow that still lurked at the edge of her vision. But for two hours a day, the whisper of turning pages and the quiet murmur of Mr. Elias’s voice were louder.

One afternoon, as he was explaining the etymology of the word ‘alkaloid’, a large, jewel-green beetle blundered in through the high window and began to buzz frantically around the room, its hard shell clacking against the walls. Mariam froze instantly. The text blurred. The familiar cold dread washed over her, making the sweat on her brow feel like ice. Her hands clamped onto the arms of her chair, her body rigid, waiting for it to land on her, to get caught in her wimple. She could feel a scream building in her chest, the same raw, helpless sound from the pantry.

Mr. Elias stopped talking. He did not look at her, but at the blundering beetle. “Ah,” he said, his voice as mild as if he were noting a change in the weather. “A Figeater beetle. *Cotinis mutabilis*. A clumsy flier. They are drawn to the scent of ripening fruit. Someone in the kitchen must have the figs out.” He stood up, fetched an empty glass jar from a shelf where they kept water for the inkwells, and waited. The beetle, exhausted, eventually settled on the wall near the door. With a slow, deliberate movement, Mr. Elias placed the jar over it and slid a piece of cardstock underneath. He carried the trapped, buzzing insect to the window and released it. The entire event took less than a minute.

He returned to his chair and adjusted his spectacles. He looked at Mariam, whose heart was still pounding a frantic rhythm against her ribs. He did not offer platitudes or prayers. He simply met her terrified gaze and said, “They have a surprisingly short adult lifespan. Only a few weeks. All that fuss just to find a mate and lay eggs in a compost heap. It seems a lot of effort for very little time.” He then tapped the manuscript. “Now, where were we? Ah, yes. Alkaloids. From the Arabic, *al-qaly*, the ashes of the saltwort plant.” He had acknowledged the source of her terror, classified it, given it a brief, almost poignant biography, and then gently led her back to the safety of their work. The scream in her chest subsided, unspoken. The world, which had narrowed to a single point of insectoid horror, slowly widened again to encompass the room, the book, and the quiet, patient man sitting opposite her.

The incident with the Figeater beetle marked a subtle but profound shift. It was as if Mr. Elias had handed her a new kind of lens. Where before she saw only monstrous, chaotic movement, she now had a name, a category, a brief, sad biography. *Cotinis mutabilis*. A clumsy flier. Drawn to fruit. A short life. It did not erase the gut-level revulsion, but it encased it in a thin, fragile layer of intellect. The fear was still a wild animal, but now she held a single, flimsy rope tied around its neck. It was a start. She began to test it, this new tool. In the courtyard, she would force herself to watch a line of ants marching with militant precision across the hot tiles. Before, she would have shuddered and looked away. Now, she would whisper to herself the things Mr. Elias might have said. *They are communicating through pheromones. Carrying food back to the colony. Each has a specific task. They are not chaos; they are a commonwealth.*

Her prayers began to change, too. The words she recited were the same, but the images in her mind were different. When she thought of God’s creation, it was no longer a static, perfect painting. It was a bustling, teeming, and often brutal ecosystem. She found herself praying for the soul of the Figeater beetle, with its brief, frantic life. She thought of the God who would design such a creature, and for the first time, it was not a question of accusation but of genuine, aching curiosity. It was a messier, more complicated divinity than the one she had worshipped in the quiet order of the scriptorium, a God of compost heaps as well as consecrated altars. This burgeoning theology felt both heretical and more honest than anything she had ever known.

Their sessions in the scriptorium became her anchor. Mr. Elias began bringing small items from his own garden, wrapped in damp cloth. A sprig of rosemary, which he crushed between his fingers, releasing its sharp, clean scent. He explained how its oils were a natural insect repellent. “See?” he’d said with a small smile. “The plants fight back.” He brought a datura flower, a beautiful, deadly white trumpet, and explained its hallucinogenic properties, the way it could kill or, in microscopic doses, ease the pain of a body in revolt. He was teaching her a new language, one of chemicals and cycles, of defense and symbiosis. He never mentioned her fear directly again, but everything he taught felt like a lesson in how to face it.

One afternoon, he brought a small block of amber-colored, transparent resin. Suspended inside, perfectly preserved, was a wasp. It was frozen mid-flight, its legs tucked, its stinger visible, its delicate, veined wings caught in the ancient sap. Mariam stared at it, her hands flat on the table. She could see every detail: the fine hairs on its legs, the complex facets of its eye, the menacing curve of its abdomen. It was a thing of terrible beauty, a nightmare captured in amber. She felt the familiar tightness in her chest, but it was distant, muffled, as if happening to someone else. It was trapped. It was history. It was, in its own way, a manuscript.

“The resin is a tree’s response to a wound,” Mr. Elias said softly, watching her face. “Something bores into its flesh, and the tree bleeds this substance to seal the injury, to push out the invader. Sometimes, it catches the invader in the process. It is a scar, and a tomb, and a perfect preservation. A single event, a moment of violence and survival, is made permanent. There is a lesson in that, I think.” He pushed the block gently across the table toward her. Her hand trembled as she reached out and touched its smooth, warm surface. She did not recoil. She traced the outline of the wasp with her fingertip, her fear held in suspension, just like the creature itself.

This quiet progress, however, was not invisible. Mother Elena’s gaze seemed to follow Mariam with a new, sharp intensity. The Abbess saw the sessions with the botanist not as a cure, but as a symptom of a deeper malaise. She saw Mariam turning to a secular man and his worldly knowledge instead of to her sisters and her God. The Abbess valued fortitude, and what she saw in Mariam was a strange, quiet rebellion cloaked in academic curiosity. She began to find reasons to interrupt them, requesting a specific book, inquiring about the progress of the translation with a tone that implied it was taking far too long.

The confrontation, when it came, was as quiet and suffocating as the humidity. Mother Elena entered the scriptorium one afternoon without knocking. Mr. Elias had just laid out several leaves on the table, showing Mariam how to identify different types of blight by the pattern of decay on their surfaces. The sweet, cloying smell of decomposition hung in the air. The Abbess’s eyes swept over the table, her nostrils flaring in distaste. “Mr. Saliba. Sister Mariam,” she said, her voice clipped. “I hope we are not turning the scriptorium into a laboratory for rot.”

Mr. Elias, ever polite, rose slightly from his chair. “Mother Abbess. We are merely examining the pathologies described in the text. To understand the cure, one must first understand the disease.”

“The only disease I am concerned with, Professor,” she said, her eyes fixed on Mariam, “is the one that infects the spirit. A fascination with decay is not a healthy one.” She turned her full attention to Mariam, who felt herself shrink under the weight of that gaze. “Sister, the convent has received a donation of new hymnals. They have been water-damaged in transit. The pages are stuck together. It will require a delicate hand to separate and dry them. A task for our best preserver of words.” Her meaning was clear. It was a test, a command to return to her proper, pristine duties and abandon this morbid new hobby.

Mariam looked from the Abbess’s stern, unyielding face to the wilting leaves on the table. A week ago, she would have murmured “Yes, Mother,” and packed Mr. Elias’s specimens away with shame. But the image of the wasp in the resin flashed in her mind—the wound, the healing, the story preserved in the scar. Her fear was a wound. This work was her strange, slow-bleeding resin. She took a breath, the air thick with the scent of dying leaves.

“Of course, Mother Elena,” Mariam said, her voice surprisingly steady. “I will attend to the hymnals this evening. But Mr. Elias and I have not yet finished our lesson for the day.” It was a small defiance, but in the rigid hierarchy of the convent, it was a tremor that shook the foundations of her world. A flicker of disbelief, then anger, crossed the Abbess’s face. She held Mariam’s gaze for a long moment, a silent battle of wills waged across the dusty air of the scriptorium. Finally, with a curt, dismissive nod, Mother Elena turned and swept out of the room, leaving a chill in her wake. Mr. Elias slowly sat back down, saying nothing, but a new, deeper respect had dawned in his eyes. He picked up one of the blighted leaves. "This pattern of necrosis," he continued, as if nothing had happened, "is fascinating. It follows the veins of the leaf, starving it from the inside out." Mariam found she could breathe again. She had not shattered.

The moment after her defiance was the loudest silence Mariam had ever known. The air, thick with the scent of decay and the Abbess’s fury, seemed to press in on her. Mr. Elias, however, simply turned his attention back to the blighted leaf, his calm a strange and powerful anchor in the turbulent quiet. He spoke of fungal spores and cellular collapse, his gravelly voice weaving a world of microscopic struggles that was both brutal and beautiful. For the first time, Mariam understood that the peace she had sought in the scriptorium was not an absence of chaos, but an understanding of its patterns. When the lesson was over, Mr. Elias packed his specimens and his worn satchel. At the door, he paused and looked back at her, his eyes kind behind his spectacles. “A scar is not a flaw, Sister,” he said softly. “It is a story of a wound that has healed.” Then he was gone, and she was alone with the story she was just beginning to write on her own soul.

That evening, she went to the small, humid room where the water-damaged hymnals were stacked. The air was thick with the smell of wet paper, a scent of neglect that would once have filled her with a tidy sense of purpose. Now, it smelled like the leaves on Mr. Elias’s table. She picked up the top book, its cover warped, the gilded cross on the front tarnished. She opened it carefully. The pages were fused together in stiff, water-stained clumps. The ink had bled, the neat black lines of sacred music running into faint, violet-blue clouds, like bruises on the page. Her old self would have seen only a task of restoration, of returning the object to its former perfection. But as she stood there, she thought of the necrosis following the veins of a leaf. The water had followed the invisible pathways of the paper’s fibers, creating its own chaotic, irreversible patterns.

With a surgeon’s delicacy she had once reserved for torn spines, she began to work, using a thin palette knife to gently separate the damp pages. In between two pages of a vespers chant, she found a small, flattened body. A silverfish, caught and crushed by the swelling paper. It was no bigger than an eyelash, its segmented body an echo of the pantry horror, but on a scale so minute it was almost abstract. She felt a flicker of the old revulsion, a cold spark in her stomach. But then she leaned closer, her mind’s eye overlaying the image with a label. *Lepisma saccharina. A wingless insect. Feeds on polysaccharides, like the starches in paper and book glue. A creature of archives and darkness.* It was not a monster. It was a librarian, of a different sort. She gently scraped the tiny, brittle corpse onto a piece of scrap paper and set it aside, then continued her work, her movements calm and measured. The hymnal would never be perfect again. The water stains, like scars, would remain. But the words, she realized, were still legible. The music could still be sung.

The days that followed were a study in polite excommunication. Mother Elena’s face was a mask of serene disapproval whenever she looked at Mariam. At meals, the small kindnesses that lubricated convent life disappeared. No one passed her the salt. Her water glass was not refilled. The other nuns, following the Abbess’s lead, spoke to her only when necessary, their voices carefully neutral. They saw a sister who had been given a spiritual trial—a simple, common fear—and had failed it, turning instead to the strange comforts of a secular man and his morbid curiosities. Mariam’s world, once a community, had shrunk to the space between her cell, the scriptorium during her lessons, and the lonely work on the hymnals. She was an island, and the sea around her was cold and silent. She bore the isolation like a penance, but it was a penance for a sin she no longer believed she had committed.

The test, when it came, was not in a dark and forgotten corner. It was in the very heart of their ordered life. It was early evening, and the nuns were gathered in the refectory for their silent supper. The long, polished wood tables reflected the fading light from the high, arched windows. The only sounds were the scrape of cutlery on ceramic plates and the gentle, lilting voice of Sister Therese, whose turn it was to read from the lives of the saints. She was reading about Saint Francis, about his love for all of God’s creatures, when a flicker of movement near the kitchen door caught Mariam’s eye.

It was one of them. A *Sarısaman*, huge and dark and glistening. It moved with a confident, liquid speed, out from the shadows and into the open space of the tiled floor. A collective, sharp intake of breath swept through the room. Sister Therese’s voice faltered and died. A young novice dropped her spoon with a clatter that sounded like a gunshot in the silence. The creature, perhaps sensing the sudden shift in the air, paused in the center of the room, its long antennae whipping back and forth, tasting their fear. Panic, sharp and metallic, flooded Mariam’s throat. Her heart hammered against her ribs, a frantic bird trapped in a cage of bone. Her body screamed at her to climb onto her chair, to flee, to give voice to the terror that was choking her.

But then, through the red haze of her fear, another voice cut through. Mr. Elias’s. *An engine of survival. Not an agent of evil. It seeks moisture, warmth, food. It is not chaos; it is an organism following its nature.* All eyes were on the cockroach, but Mariam felt the weight of Mother Elena’s gaze from the head of the table. This was it. The public trial. Hysteria or faith. Weakness or strength. She looked at the creature, really looked at it. She saw not an unholy monster, but a piece of anatomy. Carapace. Antennae. Segmented legs. A life, as driven and desperate as the Figeater beetle’s. She saw the fear on the faces of the novices and knew her own terror was mirrored there. But she was no longer one of them. She had a new set of tools.

Slowly, deliberately, Mariam pushed her chair back. The scrape of the wood was deafening. She stood up. The entire refectory watched her, frozen. She walked not away from the creature, but towards the sideboard where the serving dishes were kept. Her legs felt stiff, disconnected from her body. She picked up a heavy ceramic tureen lid, its surface cool and smooth against her trembling fingers. She turned back towards the center of the room. The cockroach, startled by her movement, had begun to scuttle towards the dark space under the long table where the Abbess sat. Mariam moved to intercept it. She did not rush. Her movements were a strange pantomime of her work in the scriptorium: precise, careful, and focused. Just as it reached the edge of the shadow, she lowered the lid, trapping it with a firm, definitive *thud* against the tiles. She did not flinch. She did not make a sound. For a moment, she simply stood there, one hand resting on the ceramic dome, breathing.

She then knelt, the wool of her habit pooling around her on the floor. With the calm of a priest performing a rite, she slid a stiff piece of card from the pocket of her habit—a page divider she had been using—under the lid, sealing the creature inside. She rose to her feet, holding her makeshift prison with both hands. She could feel the faint, frantic scrabbling from within. She walked the length of the refectory, past the stunned faces of her sisters, past the unreadable, stony visage of Mother Elena. She pushed open the heavy door to the courtyard and walked out into the gathering dusk. At the far wall, near a bed of jasmine whose scent hung thick and sweet in the humid air, she knelt again. She removed the card and tilted the lid. The dark shape scurried out and vanished into the shadows of the garden. She had not screamed. She had not fled. She had contained the chaos and escorted it out of the house. When she returned to the refectory and took her place at the table, the silence that met her was no longer cold. It was vast, and deep, and filled with a terrifying, unspoken question.

Supper was not resumed. After a moment that stretched into an eternity, Mother Elena rose with a regal stiffness that did not betray a single crack in her composure. “Sister Therese, you may cease the reading. The evening meal is concluded.” Her voice was as cool and clear as water drawn from a deep well, washing over the stunned silence and giving the other nuns permission to move. Chairs scraped, habits rustled. No one looked at Mariam directly, yet she was the undeniable center of every furtive glance, every hushed whisper that began to bloom as the sisters filed out. She remained seated, her hands resting in her lap, feeling the phantom weight of the ceramic lid. She had expected to feel triumphant, or at the very least, relieved. Instead, she felt a profound and unsettling quietude, as if she had stepped through a door and closed it so firmly behind her that she could no longer hear the sounds of the room she had left. She was not a part of their collective shock and revulsion. She was something other.

Back in the narrow quiet of her cell, she did not immediately kneel to pray. She sat on the edge of her simple cot and stared at her own hands in the pale moonlight slanting through the window. They were the same hands that mended paper, that cataloged histories, that had trembled uncontrollably in the pantry. Tonight, they had held a monster captive without crushing it. They had participated in an act that felt more authentic, more deeply true to her own evolving spirit, than a thousand recited rosaries. The fear, she realized, had not been vanquished. It had been negotiated with. She had met its mindless, scuttling purpose with her own quiet, considered purpose. She had drawn a boundary. This house is God’s, she had thought as she held the lid, and it is my home. You are also God’s, but your home is not here. The thought had been so clear, so calm, it felt less like a prayer and more like a statement of fact, a piece of data entered into a new, more expansive catalog.

The following day, the atmosphere of the convent was thick with unspoken things. The silence that surrounded Mariam was no longer condemnatory; it was cautious, laced with a new and baffling respect. During the morning chores, the young novice who had dropped her spoon, a girl named Fatima, approached Mariam while they were weeding the herb garden. She kept her head down, her fingers tugging nervously at a stubborn thistle. “Sister Mariam,” she murmured, her voice barely audible. “I… I have always been afraid of them. My mother used to say they were the Devil’s spies.” She glanced up, her dark eyes wide with a mixture of fear and wonder. “But you… you were not afraid.”

“I was,” Mariam answered, her voice soft. It was the first time she had admitted it to anyone without a sense of shame. “I am. But fear does not have to be the only thing you feel.” She looked at the thistle in Fatima’s hand. “Mr. Elias, the botanist, says this plant’s thorns are a defense. A kind of fear, made visible. But it also has a flower, if you let it grow. And its roots make a tea that is good for the heart.” Fatima stared at her, then at the plant in her hand, as if seeing it for the first time. She did not fully understand, but a seed of a new idea had been planted. Mariam was no longer just the librarian; she was becoming a translator of a different kind of text.

The summons to the Abbess’s office came, as she knew it would, just before her scheduled lesson with Mr. Elias. Mother Elena was not seated behind her imposing desk. She was standing at the window, her back to the door, looking out over the courtyard. The afternoon sun cast her familiar, formidable silhouette, turning her into a black shape against the bright light. “You have caused a great deal of talk, Sister,” the Abbess said, without turning.

“That was not my intent, Mother,” Mariam replied, her heart beginning its familiar, anxious beat.

“Intent is often irrelevant when the result is discord.” Mother Elena finally turned, her face expressionless, but her eyes were like chips of obsidian. “Last night, in the refectory, you made a spectacle. You broke the holy silence of our meal. You handled a creature of filth. And you did it all with a strange… pride.”

“It was not pride, Mother. It was… a solution. To a problem.”

“The solution to vermin is an expedient death. That is the order of things in a clean house,” the Abbess snapped, her composure finally cracking. “What you did was something else. It was a performance. You have been spending too much time with that man. He has filled your head with worldly ideas, with a fascination for the dirt and the decay we are sworn to rise above. He has taught you to find God in the mud, when you should be looking for Him in the light.”

A few weeks ago, this accusation would have crippled Mariam with guilt. Now, it felt like a confirmation. “God is in the mud, Mother,” she said, her own voice surprising her with its strength. “He is the animating force in the seed that lies dormant there. He is the chemistry in the microbes that break down the dead to create new life. He is in the light, yes, but He is also in the darkness that the light defines. The creature in the pantry did not teach me to fear the dark. It taught me that I had not been looking at it properly.”

The Abbess stared at her, truly speechless for the first time in Mariam’s memory. The woman who had a scriptural verse for every failing, a piece of dogma for every doubt, had no category for this. This was not the language of the convent. It was the language of the scriptorium, but applied to the living, breathing, scuttling world. It was the calm, analytical heresy of a librarian who had decided to recatalog Creation itself. “You are on a dangerous path, Mariam,” Mother Elena finally said, her voice low and venomous. “A path of intellectual pride. It will lead you away from your vows, and away from God. Your lessons with Mr. Saliba are at an end.”

The decree hung in the air, as final and unadorned as a tombstone. For a heartbeat, the old Mariam, the one who craved order and feared censure, surfaced and begged her to acquiesce, to bow her head and accept the Abbess’s wisdom as God’s own. But the woman who had knelt in the courtyard and released the thing she feared most was no longer that person. The silence stretched, and in that space, Mariam found her voice. It was quiet, but it did not tremble. “Mother, you assigned me the translation of the botanical manuscripts. A duty. Professor Saliba’s expertise is essential to fulfilling that duty with accuracy. Without him, the work is merely transcription, not true preservation of knowledge.”

Mother Elena’s eyes narrowed. She had expected submission, perhaps tears. This calm, reasoned opposition was a far greater insolence. “Accuracy in a book of herbs is of less importance than the purity of a soul in this house. The work will be completed as you are able, without outside influence. You are a nun, Sister Mariam, not a university scholar. Remember your place.” She gestured toward the door, a dismissal that was as absolute as an excommunication. “Go and pray for humility. Pray that God removes this prideful intellectualism from your heart before it chokes out your faith entirely.”

Mariam left the office, the chill of the Abbess’s final words clinging to her like a damp shroud. There was no argument against such certainty. The next afternoon, at two o’clock, she sat at her table in the scriptorium. The worn wooden chair opposite hers was empty. The dusty shafts of light illuminated a space where Mr. Elias should have been, his worn satchel on the floor, his spectacles perched on his nose. The silence was no longer peaceful. It was the heavy, profound silence of absence, a soundless testament to what had been taken from her. She waited, a small, foolish part of her hoping the Abbess might relent, hoping the familiar, shuffling footsteps would sound in the hall. But only the distant groan of the air conditioner answered. The hour of their lesson came and went. He was not coming.

She felt the loss like a physical ache, a hollow space carved out in her chest. For a moment, despair was a tide, threatening to pull her back under, to strand her again on the shores of her fear. But then she looked at the open manuscript on the table before her, the *De herbis et plantis*. She saw the elegant script, the intricate drawing of a plant’s root system. Mr. Elias was gone, but his lessons remained. He had not just given her answers; he had given her a methodology. He had taught her how to look, how to ask questions, how to find the pattern in the chaos. With a slow, deliberate movement, she pulled a blank sheet of paper towards her and picked up a pen. Beside the Latin entry for Sea Squill, she began to make her own annotation, in neat, precise Arabic. *‘Highly toxic,’* she wrote. *‘Professor E. Saliba notes that application as a dried powder, rather than a direct mixture, allows for precise dosage. A lesson in the separation of potent elements. A principle of medicine, and perhaps of life.’* She had become a two-way street: a preserver of the old text, and a chronicler of the new knowledge. The scriptorium was her laboratory now. The chair opposite her was empty, but she was no longer alone.

Her world became a text to be read. Weeding the courtyard garden was no longer a mindless chore. She found herself observing the tiny, green aphids clustered on the underside of a rose leaf, and instead of revulsion, she felt a clinical curiosity. She saw the way they followed the delicate veins, sucking the life from the plant, and thought of Mother Elena’s words, ‘starving it from the inside out.’ She watched a spider spin its impossibly intricate web between the bars of a window, a perfect structure built to capture the unwary, and saw not a menace, but a masterful engineer. She was cataloging the world, finding a place for everything, even the things she did not love. The fear was still there, a low note humming in the background of her life, but it was now just one note in a vast and complex symphony.

This quiet transformation did not go unnoticed. The younger nuns, especially, watched her with a kind of covert fascination. They had seen her terror, and now they saw her strange, calm strength. One afternoon, Sister Fatima approached her, not in the public space of the garden, but in the relative privacy of the scriptorium. She was holding a single, drooping rose from the bush they had tended, its petals brown and wilted at the edges. “Sister Mariam,” she whispered, as if sharing a dangerous secret. “Mother Elena said to prune the whole branch, that it was diseased. But it is the only one with a new bud.” Mariam took the flower, her fingers gentle on the stem. She turned the leaves over, her eyes scanning their surface with a practiced gaze. “It is not a disease,” she said softly. “It’s aphids. See the sticky residue? It’s called honeydew. They are farming the bush.” She looked at Fatima’s earnest, worried face. “Mr. Elias said that the harshest solution is not always the wisest. Go to the kitchen. Ask for a small piece of unscented soap. We will make a wash. We will not kill the branch to save the flower.” In that moment, offering a simple, worldly cure, Mariam realized she was stepping fully into a new role. She was no longer just the keeper of dead words; she was becoming a tender of living things.

The lesson in the rose garden became a quiet sacrament. Under the bruised purple of the evening sky, Mariam showed Fatima how to dissolve the soap in a bucket of warm water, how to agitate it until a thin film of iridescent bubbles covered the surface. Her movements were patient and precise, the way she had once taught novices to handle gold leaf. She explained how the soap solution would not poison the aphids, but would break the surface tension of the water on their waxy bodies, penetrating their breathing spiracles and suffocating them. It was, she explained, a matter of physics, not wrath. Fatima listened, rapt, her face illuminated by the reflected glow of the water. They applied the wash with soft rags, gently wiping down the afflicted leaves and stems. It was an act of cleaning, of healing, a laying-on of hands that was both profoundly earthly and deeply spiritual. Days later, the tiny, perfect bud on the end of the branch, which Mother Elena would have condemned, unfurled into a rose of the most delicate, creamy white. It seemed to shine in the courtyard, a small flag of defiance.

The miracle of the resurrected rose did not go unnoticed. Soon, the scriptorium, once the sole domain of silent words, became a place of hushed consultations. Sister Agnes came to her, her face a mask of frustration, complaining of a persistent, musty smell and a dark, creeping stain on the wall of her cell, which faced the sea. Mother Elena had told her it was a sign of spiritual sloth, a physical manifestation of a neglected prayer life, and had prescribed an extra decade of the rosary. Mariam, however, asked about the window frame. She went with Agnes and ran her fingers along the crumbling mortar. She tapped the wall, listening to the sound. “It is not sloth, Sister,” Mariam said, her voice low. “It is salt. The sea air is corrosive. The mortar is failing, and the humidity is seeping into the coral stone. It is a weakness in the foundation, not in your soul.” She suggested a mixture of vinegar and clove oil to kill the mildew, but stressed the true cure was structural. “We must tell the Abbess the wall needs repointing.” Agnes stared at her, the simple, physical diagnosis a greater comfort than any prayer had been.

The word spread through the quiet corridors like a vine. A kitchen sister, wringing her hands over weevils in the semolina, was told to place bay leaves in the flour bins, a trick of old wives that Mr. Elias had mentioned. A novice whose white wimples were perpetually yellowed by the hard water was shown how to add a splash of lemon juice to the final rinse. These were small, practical acts of salvation, whispered heresies of common sense. Mariam never undermined the Abbess directly. She never suggested prayer was useless. Instead, she operated in a parallel world, one where the divine expressed itself not only in scripture, but in the chemical properties of a lemon, the repellent oils of a bay leaf, the slow, inexorable decay of mortar. She was treating the body of the convent, while Mother Elena ministered to a soul she perceived as increasingly sick.

Mother Elena was a woman who understood power, and she recognized a rival sovereignty when she saw one. She saw the way the younger nuns now watched Mariam, the way Sister Agnes no longer complained of her damp wall but spoke of lime-to-water ratios. She could not forbid acts of kindness, nor punish the dispensing of practical advice. So she fought back on her own terms. During the morning chapter, she announced a week of special observance. There would be additional prayer services, a stricter fast, and a period of contemplative silence to be observed outside of necessary duties. “Our community has become distracted,” she declared, her eyes sweeping over the assembled sisters and resting, for a long moment, on Mariam. “We have grown too comfortable with the things of this world. We have sought remedies in powders and solutions, when the only true remedy for any affliction is a humble and contrite heart. We will turn our focus back to God, and away from the corrupting influence of earthly knowledge, which puffs up the spirit with pride.”

It was a public rebuke, as elegant as it was brutal. Mariam was assigned the most humbling of tasks: the cleaning of all the mashrabiya screens throughout the convent. These intricate, wooden lattices were the architectural glory of the old house, but they were also a nightmare to clean, each tiny, carved segment a trap for the ochre dust of the chamsin winds. The task was meant to occupy her hands and empty her mind, to force her back into a state of meditative, repetitive labor. For two days, Mariam obeyed in silence. With a soft brush and a damp cloth, she worked her way through the patterns of hexagons and stars, her world narrowed to the few inches of wood before her eyes. It was on the third day, while cleaning the magnificent screen that overlooked the inner courtyard from the Abbess’s own office corridor, that her new way of seeing intersected with her old world.

As her brush worked into a particularly complex joint at the base of the screen, she noticed the dust was different. It was not the fine, reddish powder of the desert, but a paler, grittier substance, like fine sawdust. She paused, a prickle of unease running up her spine. She tapped the thick, carved base of the screen. Instead of the solid thud of aged teak, the sound was papery, hollow. Leaning closer, she saw a series of tiny, almost invisible holes in the wood, no larger than a pinprick. The scent that came from them was faint, but it was a smell she was now coming to know: the smell of decay, of slow, methodical destruction. With the tip of a metal bookbinding needle she kept in her pocket, she gently probed one of the holes. The wood around it crumbled into dust. And then she saw it. A single, pale, wingless creature, the size of a grain of rice, with a soft, creamy body and a small, brown head. It was a termite. A soldier. And where there was one, there were millions. They were inside the walls, in the floors, silently, diligently, un-making the world around her. She stared at the insect on the tip of her needle, a creature that had been thriving in the darkness, completely hidden from the eyes of faith. The foundation of the Convent of the Blessed Oasis, her sanctuary, was being devoured from within. And she, the cataloger of chaos, was the only one who knew.

Mariam stood motionless, the tiny, pale body of the termite impaled on the tip of her bookbinding needle. The world seemed to shrink to that single, horrifying point. It was not the fast, frantic horror of the cockroach, a singular invader that could be contained and expelled. This was something far more insidious. This was evidence of a silent, secret commonwealth, a hidden nation thriving within the very bones of her sanctuary. She thought of the Figeater beetle’s brief, clumsy life, the ant’s militant purpose, the cockroach’s desperate search for sustenance. This creature, this soldier, was different. It was part of a superorganism, a vast, hungry entity that did not just visit the house of God, but consumed it. They were remaking the convent in their own image, turning carved wood into hollowed-out dust, structure into fragility, all while the nuns above prayed for the salvation of their souls, oblivious to the damnation of their walls.

A cold, clear dread settled over her, a feeling entirely different from the hot panic of the pantry. This was not a failure of her nerves; it was the precise, analytical terror of a librarian discovering that the archive itself is on fire. She looked up at the magnificent, sun-drenched mashrabiya. It was a testament to a century of faith, a screen designed to filter the harsh light of the world, to create a space of cool, patterned piety. And it was a lie. A beautiful, hollow façade, its strength a memory. Her mind, the cataloging mind that Mr. Elias had helped her retrain, began to work. She saw not just this one screen, but the vast, interconnected network of beams, floorboards, and joists that held the Convent of the Blessed Oasis together. She saw the termites moving along these hidden pathways like a slow, deliberate poison, following the veins of the house, starving it from the inside out. Mother Elena saw pride as a spiritual cancer. Mariam was now looking at the real thing, a literal and voracious cancer eating away at their home.

She carefully scraped the termite soldier into an empty matchbox she carried for her small tools. She collected a sample of the granular dust, a testament to the creature’s work, folding it carefully into a scrap of paper. This was not a story. It was not a feeling. It was data. Evidence. She knew, with a certainty that chilled her to the bone, that she had to present this to Mother Elena. And she knew, with equal certainty, how the Abbess would receive it. She would see it as another of Mariam’s morbid obsessions, a projection of her own spiritual decay onto the house itself. *You see rot everywhere because it is in your heart.* The words formed in Mariam’s mind, a perfect mimicry of the Abbess’s tone. To go to Mother Elena with this discovery was not just to report a pest problem. It was to challenge the very foundation of the Abbess’s worldview, to insist that the most profound threats were not always spiritual, and that humility sometimes meant admitting your house was falling down.

She waited until after the evening prayers, after the failed ritual of community supper had been endured in near-complete silence. She knocked on the door of the Abbess’s office, her heart a steady, heavy drum against her ribs. She was not the terrified woman who had fled the pantry; she was a diagnostician bearing a terrible prognosis. When Mother Elena opened the door, her face was a mask of weary impatience. “Sister Mariam. If this is about your cleaning duties—”

“It is not, Mother,” Mariam said, her voice even. “May I have a moment? It concerns the structural integrity of the convent.” The phrase, so formal and so secular, hung in the air between them. It was a phrase from the world of engineers and foremen, not from the world of prayer and piety. Intrigued despite herself, the Abbess stepped back, gesturing for Mariam to enter. She did not invite her to sit.

Mariam walked to the center of the room, under the Abbess’s unforgiving gaze. She did not begin with apologies or supplications. She opened her hand and presented the small, folded paper. “While cleaning the mashrabiya outside your office, I found this.” She unfolded the paper, revealing the gritty pile of wood dust on the polished surface of the Abbess’s desk. “At first, I thought it was just dust from the desert.” Mother Elena stared at the small pile with open distaste. “And?” she prompted, her voice sharp. Mariam then produced the matchbox, sliding it open to reveal the pale, dead body of the termite soldier. “Then I found the source. This is a termite. The wood of the screen, and I suspect many of the main support beams, is infested. The dust is not from the outside, Mother. It is the convent itself, being eaten from within.”

A dangerous silence filled the room. The Abbess looked from the dead insect to Mariam’s face, and her expression was not one of alarm, but of cold, gathering fury. “So it has come to this,” she said, her voice deceptively soft. “Your obsession has graduated from fleeting beetles and common roaches to a full-scale fantasy of destruction. You have been looking for a monster, Sister, and since the world has not provided one grand enough for your drama, you have decided to imagine one in the very walls of this holy place.” She made a dismissive gesture at the evidence on her desk. “This house was built from the finest teak and coral stone. It has weathered a hundred years of heat and storms. It will not be brought down by your fevered imagination and a dead ant.”

“It is not an ant, Mother,” Mariam said, her calm unwavering. She refused to be drawn into an argument about her spirit. This was about facts. “It is a Coptotermes formosanus, most likely. They are notorious for colonizing structures in humid climates. They create subterranean nests and can hollow out a beam completely, leaving only a thin veneer of wood on the surface. Everything looks strong until it collapses.” She used the words of Mr. Elias, a litany of classification and function. It was her new armor.

The use of the scientific name was a spark on dry tinder. “Enough!” The Abbess’s voice cracked like a whip. “I will not have this language in my office! This is a house of God, not a laboratory for your profane curiosities. You were given a task of humility, and you have twisted it into an act of supreme arrogance, presuming to know the secret decay of this building better than I, who have been its guardian for thirty years. Your pride is the infestation, Mariam. It is what is hollowing you out. I will pray for you. Now, leave.” But Mariam did not move. She looked past the Abbess, toward the grand window behind her desk, the one that offered a commanding view of the city. “Prayer will not kill a colony, Mother,” she said, her voice dropping to an intense whisper. “And faith will not hold up a roof when the beams that support it have turned to dust. You are the guardian of this house. Not just its soul, but its body. And its body is sick. If you do nothing, you are not failing to trust in God. You are failing to see what He has put right in front of your eyes.” She held the Abbess’s furious gaze for a moment longer, then bowed her head slightly, turned, and walked out of the office, leaving the evidence of the slow, silent apocalypse sitting on the polished desk, a tiny pile of dust and a single, dead soldier.

Mariam did not return their gazes. Her eyes remained fixed on the ruined rosette, the dark, exposed wound in the ceiling of the chapel. There was no triumph in her heart, only a deep, aching sorrow. This was not a victory; it was a disfigurement. The sight confirmed her knowledge, but it also desecrated a space she loved. She saw it with the twin vision that had become her blessing and her curse: she saw the failure of faith to acknowledge the physical world, and she saw the brutal, mindless industry of a million hungry mouths. The silence in the chapel was absolute, a vacuum where prayer and piety had been only moments before. It was a silence filled with the truth, as raw and exposed as the crumbling wood in the ceiling. In that moment, Mariam was no longer the hysteric, the morbid eccentric. She was the prophet whose prophecy had just come terribly, tangibly true.

Mother Elena was the first to break the spell. She rose to her feet, her movements stiff, her face a mask of disbelief struggling against the undeniable evidence before her. Her authority, built on an unshakeable conviction in a divinely protected order, had been publicly compromised not by a spiritual failing, but by a physical one. She looked at the sagging rosette, then at the faces of her nuns, all turned toward the one sister who had foretold this. The Abbess’s world, a fortress of dogma, had been breached, and the enemy was not the Devil, but gravity. "The vigil is over," she said, her voice strained, stripped of its usual resonance. "Return to your cells. Sister Agnes, see that the chapel is cordoned off." She turned, her back rigid with a shame that was almost palpable, and swept out of the chapel without another word, without a single glance at Mariam.

The dismantling of the Abbess’s authority, once begun, was swift and quiet. It was not a rebellion, but a realignment. The next morning, Sister Agnes did not cordon off the chapel. Instead, she found Mariam in the scriptorium. The older nun, her face etched with grim pragmatism, placed a heavy iron crowbar on the table beside a 15th-century psalter. "The storeroom behind the kitchen," she said without preamble. "The floorboards have been soft for a year. Mother Elena said it was damp from the sea. I think it's time we looked." It was a declaration of allegiance, a transfer of power based not on holy orders but on observable reality. Mariam looked at the crude tool lying next to the delicate, illuminated manuscript. It was the juxtaposition of her entire life: the preservation of the past and the desperate, messy work of saving the future.

They went together, Mariam and Agnes, a silent procession of two. The storeroom was dark and smelled of mildew and stale rice. Agnes pointed to a section of the floor. With the focused energy of a woman whose practical nature had been suppressed for too long, she jammed the tip of the crowbar into a seam between two wide planks. The wood, which should have been as strong as iron, gave way with a sickening, soft crunch. When she heaved back on the bar, the plank did not splinter; it tore like wet cardboard. The two women peered into the darkness below. What they saw was a nightmare of engineering. The massive subfloor beam beneath was almost entirely gone, its surface a thin, hollow shell. The interior had been transformed into a grotesque architecture of layered, earthen tunnels, pulsing with a pale, maggot-like river of termites. They were a silent, single-minded city, deconstructing the world of God to build their own. Agnes let out a low whistle of disbelief, a sound of pure, unadorned awe at the sheer scale of the destruction.

News of the discovery in the storeroom moved through the convent not like a whisper, but like a tremor. There was no longer any room for doubt, no space for spiritual metaphor. The threat was real, it was total, and the Abbess had been wrong. The nuns, conditioned to a life of obedience, found themselves adrift. Their leader was cloistered in her office, a prisoner of her own shattered certainty, leaving a vacuum of authority. And into that vacuum stepped Sister Mariam, not with commands, but with quiet, purposeful action. She began to map the house, tapping on walls, probing beams, her bookbinding needle her only instrument. Sister Fatima became her scribe, drawing a floor plan of the convent on a large sheet of vellum, marking in red ink the areas Mariam identified as compromised. The scriptorium was transformed from a place of quiet contemplation into a command center for a war no one had known they were fighting.

The change was most profound in Mariam herself. The fear, the revulsion that had once paralyzed her, was burned away by the sheer magnitude of the problem. A single cockroach could be a monster, but a million termites were a logistical challenge. Her mind, the mind for systems that Mother Elena had once praised, was fully engaged. She researched, using the convent's old encyclopedia and a modern botany text Mr. Elias had conveniently "forgotten" in the scriptorium. She learned about bait systems, about chemical barriers, about the necessity of finding the queen. She was no longer just a librarian; she was a strategist, a biologist, a structural engineer. She was fighting for the body of the convent, and in doing so, she was healing her own soul in a way prayer had never been able to. She was finding the divine, not in the ecstatic pronouncements of saints, but in the meticulous, desperate work of survival. She was finding God in the details, and the details were a matter of life and death.

The vellum map lay spread across the great reading table in the scriptorium, a pale and beautiful skin marked with the angry red cartography of its own disease. Sister Fatima’s hand had been steady, her lines neat, but the image they created was one of pure chaos. Red ink bled along the floor plan, tracing the path of the termite colony from the storeroom, up through the walls of the refectory, branching into the west wing where the novices slept, and culminating in the dark, gaping wound in the ceiling of the chapel. It looked like a diagram of a diseased lung, the infection spreading relentlessly along the bronchioles of the convent’s hidden structure. For three days, this map had been their scripture, their focus of meditation and their source of dread. Sister Agnes would stare at it, her broad hands clenched into fists, as if she could physically will the building to be whole again. Mariam, however, saw it as a problem of logistics, a vast, complex system that needed to be understood before it could be dismantled.

“We have identified the extent of the primary infestation,” Mariam said, her voice quiet but carrying the weight of command in the still room. She pointed with the tip of her needle to a section near the foundations. “But there are likely satellite colonies. And we cannot see what is happening in the roof beams above the second floor. We are only seeing the edges of the problem.” She looked from Agnes’s grim face to Fatima’s worried one. “We have done all we can with what we have. A needle and a crowbar will not save this house. We need help. We need knowledge we do not possess, and tools we cannot wield.” The unspoken words hung in the air between them: they needed men, they needed poison, they needed money. They needed to open the gates and let in the loud, messy, secular world they had sworn to leave behind. It was Agnes, the pragmatist, who gave voice to the truth. “We need an army, Sister. And armies are expensive. Mother Elena holds the accounts.”

The name of the Abbess fell into the room like a stone, rippling the tense surface of their work. She remained in her self-imposed exile, a ghost of authority haunting the upper corridors, her meals taken in her office, her presence at prayers a stiff, silent rebuke to the new order of things. To approach her would be to invite a lecture on the vanity of earthly works, a sermon on humility while the floorboards crumbled. Mariam knew they could not go through her. They would have to go around. That evening, long after the final prayers, Mariam slipped out of her cell. The convent was dark and still, a sleeping creature unaware of the cancer that devoured it. She made her way to the small anteroom of the Abbess’s office, where the convent’s only telephone sat on a small table, a black, utilitarian object that was their one official link to the world outside. Its use was strictly controlled by Mother Elena. To use it without permission was a profound breach of protocol. Mariam’s hand trembled as she picked up the heavy receiver. The dial tone felt like a roar in the silence. With methodical care, she dialed the number she had memorized from the cover of the book he had left behind, the number for the botany department at the university. After a series of transfers, a sleepy security guard finally patched her through to a number he had for the retired professor. His voice, when it finally came on the line, was a soft, gravelly hum, and the sound of it was the first real peace Mariam had felt in days. “Mr. Saliba,” she whispered into the receiver, her back pressed against the cold wall. “It’s Sister Mariam. I need your help.”

He arrived the next morning, not with a satchel of leaves, but with a heavy canvas tool bag and a powerful flashlight. Sister Agnes met him at the gate, a silent co-conspirator, and led him not to the formal reception room, but directly to the scene of the crime in the storeroom. He knelt by the hole in the floor, shining his beam into the grotesque, pulsating architecture of the nest. He did not flinch. He simply observed, his expression one of a grimly fascinated physician examining a terminal patient. He took samples, scraped away layers of the hollowed-out beam, and peered into the darkness with a small magnifying glass. He moved through the convent like a ghost, following the red lines on Fatima’s map, tapping walls, listening, his presence a quiet, scientific judgment on the state of the house. He spent a long time in the chapel, his light tracing the path of destruction from the floor to the ruined rosette. “You were right, Sister,” he said to Mariam, his voice low as they stood in the desecrated holy space. “They followed a water leak from a corroded pipe in the wall. The damp wood was an invitation. They have been feasting for years.”

That afternoon, in the scriptorium, he laid out the unvarnished truth. The convent nuns gathered around the table—Agnes, Fatima, and a half-dozen others who had quietly joined Mariam’s cause—listened as Mr. Elias spoke in a language they had never heard within these walls. He spoke of cubic meters of infested wood, of load-bearing walls, of the need for soil testing and chemical barriers. He spoke of fumigation, of tenting the entire historic building in a shroud of vinyl and pumping it full of sulfuryl fluoride gas. He spoke of structural engineers who would need to assess the damage to the main beams and the potential for catastrophic collapse. And then, he spoke of the cost. He laid a piece of paper on the table with a number written on it, a figure so large it seemed to have no connection to their world of simple meals and mended habits. It was an apocalyptic sum, a number that represented a reality more terrifying than any demon or spiritual trial. A dead silence fell over the room. Saving their sanctuary would bankrupt the Order.

Armed with Mr. Elias’s informal, hand-written report and that terrifying number, Mariam knew what she had to do. This was no longer a matter of opinion or interpretation; it was a matter of survival. She knocked on the Abbess’s door once more. This time, she did not wait to be invited in. She opened the door and found Mother Elena sitting behind her desk, not praying, but staring blankly at the wall. The office was stale with unaired thoughts. “Mother,” Mariam began, her voice devoid of supplication. She placed the papers on the desk. “Professor Saliba has completed his assessment. The infestation is advanced and systemic. The main roof beam above the chapel is compromised. He believes we are in danger of a larger collapse. Here is his report, and here is a preliminary estimate for the fumigation and necessary structural repairs.”

Mother Elena looked at the papers as if they were venomous snakes. She did not touch them. A deep, shuddering breath escaped her. For a moment, Mariam thought she might weep. But the Abbess’s pride was a fortress, and its walls were ancient and thick. She raised her head, her eyes burning with a cold, desperate fire. “And so you have done it,” she whispered, her voice rough with fury. “You have brought your worldly chaos into this house. You would have us evicted from our own home, shrouded in poison, crawling with loud, faithless men tearing down our walls. You would destroy the sanctity of this convent to save the stones. Is that it, Mariam? Is that your great victory?” Mariam met her gaze without wavering. The fate of their world rested in this exchange. "A sanctuary must have a foundation, Mother," she replied, her voice soft but unyielding. "You cannot have a soul without a body. God has given us the minds to see this problem and the means to fix it. To do nothing now, to let this house fall down around us out of pride, is not an act of faith. It is the purest form of despair.”

The words fell into the suffocating quiet of the office and did not echo. They were absorbed, drawn into the vacuum of Mother Elena’s shattered composure. Mariam watched as something fundamental in the Abbess broke. It was not a sound, but a subsidence, like a snowdrift collapsing under its own weight. The rigid posture that had defined her for decades softened, the sharp lines of her shoulders rounding as if a great and terrible burden had suddenly become too heavy to bear. Her gaze dropped from Mariam’s face to the papers on her desk. With a hand that trembled almost imperceptibly, she reached out and touched Mr. Elias’s report, her fingers tracing the edge of the paper as if it were a sacred relic or an object of profound contamination. Her eyes, empty of their fire, finally settled on the number, the apocalyptic sum that represented the price of their physical salvation. It was a figure she could not comprehend, a worldly fact so large and brutal it rendered her entire arsenal of scripture and dogma obsolete. A long, shuddering sigh escaped her, the sound of a fortress surrendering. When she finally spoke, her voice was a ghost of its former self, a dry whisper of rustling leaves. “Do what you must,” she said, her eyes still fixed on the desk. She did not look at Mariam. She could not. It was an abdication, a quiet and devastating capitulation. Mariam bowed her head, a gesture not of submission but of somber acknowledgment, and left the Abbess alone with the ruins of her certainty.

The week that followed was a blur of strange and unprecedented activity. A formal letter, drafted by Mariam and signed with Mother Elena’s shaky, unadorned signature, was dispatched to the Mother Superior of their Order in Rome. The reply came via a terse telegram, a medium as foreign to their lives as the crisis it addressed: APPROVAL GRANTED. FUNDS TO BE WIRED. PROCEED. With that, the ancient, invisible walls between the Convent of the Blessed Oasis and the city of Jeddah crumbled. The change began with a sound: the guttural roar of a diesel engine idling outside their gate. It was a sound of commerce, of labor, of a world that did not pause for prayer five times a day. Sister Agnes, her face set in a grim mask of determination, unbarred the heavy wooden gate, and the world rolled in on four wheels. The man who stepped out of the truck was the antithesis of everything the convent represented. He was broad and sun-darkened, his white thobe stained with dust and sweat. He introduced himself as Mr. Boulos, the foreman of the pest control company, his voice a practical, booming baritone that seemed to physically push back the convent’s delicate silence. He held a clipboard like a scepter.

Mariam met him in the courtyard. She was his designated point of contact, a role that had been tacitly and unanimously assigned to her. The other nuns watched from the shadows of the arcades and the latticed screens of the upper windows, their faces a mixture of fear, fascination, and profound unease. “Sister Mariam,” Mr. Boulos said, his tone one of professional courtesy, not reverence. He was already scanning the roofline, his expert eye assessing angles and square footage. “We will need to clear all vegetation within two meters of the main building. My men will begin erecting the scaffolding this afternoon. All residents will need to be evacuated from the main house by tomorrow morning. We will begin sealing the structure at dawn.” He handed her the clipboard. On it was a multi-page checklist of protocols and warnings, a secular litany of chemicals and procedures. Mariam took it, the plastic cool and foreign in her hands. She had become a translator once more, not between languages, but between worlds.

The shrouding of the convent was a slow, ritualistic violation. An army of men in dusty overalls swarmed over the building, their shouted instructions and the rhythmic clang of metal poles creating a cacophony that grated on the nuns’ silent sensibilities. They erected a metal skeleton around the old merchant’s house, a cage of scaffolding that stripped it of its grace. Then came the great, striped shrouds of thick, heavy vinyl. Rolled out in enormous bolts, they were hoisted upwards, their garish blue and white stripes a bizarre imposition on the warm tones of the coral stone and dark wood. The men moved with a practiced efficiency, sealing the seams with wide, hissing tape, transforming the familiar, beloved architecture into a series of stark, geometric planes. The courtyard, with its fragrant jasmine and ancient, gnarled olive tree, became a staging ground. The nuns, displaced and disoriented, moved their cots and personal effects into the refectory and kitchens, modern annexes that were not part of the main infestation. They became refugees in their own home, watching as their sanctuary, their world, was systematically erased from view.

By the end of the second day, it was done. The Convent of the Blessed Oasis was gone. In its place stood a monstrous, striped box, a silent, featureless monolith that shimmered in the heat. It was utterly alien. Warning signs in Arabic and English, featuring stark skulls and crossbones, were plastered on the vinyl seals. The only sounds were the low, expectant hum of the powerful fans and generators that would pump the poison gas into the building’s hollowed-out heart. That evening, as the sun set and cast long, distorted shadows, Mariam stood before the shrouded building. She reached out and placed her palm flat against the vinyl. It was taut and warm, like the skin of a drum. Beneath that skin, the house she loved was waiting to be filled with a killing fog. She felt no triumph, only a profound and complex sorrow. She had fought a war to save this body, and the first step was to pronounce it dead, to seal it in a tomb and entrust its resurrection to a science she barely understood. The rhythmic groan of the old air conditioner had been replaced by the hum of the generators. It was a new sound of persistence, a mechanical prayer against the inevitable, and Mariam, the Abbess of this strange and terrible healing, was the only one left to hear it.

The three days of waiting were a purgatory of noise and idleness. The convent had always been a vessel for ordered sound—the hushed turning of a page, the distant call to prayer, the gentle chime for vespers. Now, it was a cacophony. The relentless, deep-throated hum of the generators was the foundation of their new life, a sound that vibrated through the floor tiles and into their bones, a constant reminder of the alien presence that had consumed their home. To this was added the unfiltered sounds of the city: the blare of car horns, the shouts of street vendors, the rumble of trucks on the nearby port road. The mashrabiya screens and thick coral walls had been a membrane, selectively filtering the world. Now, living in the modern, thin-walled kitchen and refectory annex, that membrane was gone. They were exposed.

Their new world was a cramped and public affair. Cots were arranged in neat rows in the refectory, the long, polished tables where they had taken their silent meals now piled high with displaced linens and personal prayer books. Privacy, a cornerstone of the contemplative life, was a luxury they no longer possessed. They dressed and undressed behind makeshift screens of hanging blankets, the silhouettes of their sisters moving like shadow puppets in the dim light. Their life of quiet, individual devotion had been forcibly replaced by a life of inescapable, messy community. Sister Agnes, with the grim efficiency of a quartermaster, took charge of the logistics, organizing meal preparations and cleaning rotas with a militaristic zeal. It was a necessary, grounding work, but it did little to soothe the frayed nerves and unsettled spirits of the other nuns. They were a flock without their pasture, huddling together against a strange wind, their shepherdess a silent, broken woman who took her meals alone in the small office off the kitchen.

On the morning of the fumigation, Mr. Boulos found Mariam overseeing the brewing of tea. His presence was a solid, earthy fact in their ethereal, unsettled world. He smelled of diesel and strong coffee. "Sister," he said, holding his ever-present clipboard. "We are ready to begin the introduction of the gas. The seals are secure. My men will monitor the pressure levels from our station outside the gate. The process will take seventy-two hours." He looked at her, his expression not unkind. "There is nothing to see. It is a quiet process." Mariam nodded, thanking him. She walked to the window that overlooked the courtyard, now a wasteland of trampled grass and coiled hoses, dominated by the monstrous, striped wall of the tent. She could not see anything, just as he said. But she could feel it. A subtle shift in the pitch of the generators' hum, a new note of purpose in their monotonous song. The killing fog was being born, a silent, invisible tide rising within the walls of her home, seeping into the wood, filling the sacred spaces of the chapel and the ordered shelves of her scriptorium. It was seeking out the secret, silent life that had thrived in the dark and was now extinguishing it. It was a necessary violence, a chemical exorcism, and she, its architect, felt a profound and terrible responsibility. This was the true meaning of a poultice, she thought. To draw out the poison, the cure itself had to be a kind of poison.

That evening, the fragile composure of the community began to fray. A young novice, overwrought and homesick, began to weep uncontrollably, her sobs echoing in the crowded refectory. Sister Therese tried to comfort her with whispered prayers, but the girl was inconsolable, mourning not just her home but the loss of a world she had understood. At the same time, from a corner of the room, Mother Elena emerged. She had not joined them for the evening meal, but now she walked slowly to the water cooler, a ghost at a feast she had not been invited to. Her wimple was slightly askew, a detail so jarring that several nuns fell silent, staring. She moved without her usual gliding authority, her feet shuffling slightly on the tiles. She drank a cup of water, her back to the room, and then retreated to her office without a word. Her presence was a judgment and a plea, a walking embodiment of their broken order. Mariam watched it all, the novice’s raw grief and the Abbess’s silent shame, and felt her heart cleave in two. She was the fulcrum, the point on which all this weight was balanced, and she feared she would snap.

Later, as a fragile quiet settled over the makeshift dormitory, Sister Fatima approached Mariam where she sat mending a torn altar cloth. The girl’s eyes were wide with a curiosity that seemed to eclipse her fear. “Sister,” she whispered, “Mr. Elias explained that the gas is heavier than air. But how will it reach the roof beams? And the books… your books in the scriptorium. Will it stain them? Will the words fade?” Mariam put down her needle, grateful for the anchor of a practical question. She explained, in the simple, clear terms the botanist had used with her, how the powerful fans created a constant circulation, forcing the gas into every crack and crevice, how the chemical was non-residual and would not harm paper or fabric. “It only affects living things, Fatima,” she said softly. “It interrupts the way they process energy. It is very specific.” Fatima listened, her brow furrowed in concentration. “So it is a clever poison,” she concluded. Mariam nodded. “Or a very specific prayer, answered with chemistry.” The girl considered this, then a small smile touched her lips. She had found a way to fit this new, terrifying knowledge into her worldview, a small act of translation that made the world make sense again.

When the last of the nuns had fallen into a restless sleep, Mariam stepped outside into the warm, humid night. The striped tent loomed before her, a silent, cyclopean beast, its skin faintly luminous in the moonlight. The hum of the generators was the sound of its breathing.
